discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-policy/security-profiles/security-profile-anti-spyware

D. Reset-both

This action resets the connection on both the client and server sides if a threat is detected
Answer is D

Selected Answer: D
When a threat event is detected, you can configure the following actions in an Anti-Spyware profile:
Default—For each threat signature and Anti-Spyware signature that is defined by Palo Alto Networks, a default action is specified internally. Typically the default action is an alert or a reset-both. The default action is displayed in parenthesis, for example default (alert) in the threat or Antivirus signature.

Selected Answer: D
Reset both or alert

questions.question_text: What is the Anti-Spyware Security profile default action?

discussion.content:
B. IPv6 D. IPv4

These are the IP addresses that are resolved to the default Palo Alto Networks sinkhole IP address12. The IP addresses currently are IPv4—sinkhole.paloaltonetworks.com and a loopback address IPv6 address—::12. These addresses are subject to change and can be updated with content updates

Correct answer IPv4 and IPv6:
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClGECA0

questions.question_text: To enable DNS sinkholing, which two addresses should be reserved? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Device > Admin Roles > Add > XML API > Operational Request
choices.A: Device > Admin Roles > Add > XML API > Configuration
choices.D: Device > Admin Roles > Add > Web UI > Operations
choices.C: Device > Admin Roles > Add > Web UI > Support

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A firewall administrator profile in Palo Alto Networks can be customized using Admin Roles to grant or restrict specific permissions.

To allow the administrator to:
Download TSF (Technical Support File)
Start Dump File
But NOT allow rebooting the device,

The "Operations" section in the Web UI provides granular control over operational tasks, such as:
Generating & downloading TSF files
Capturing system dump files
Restarting services (but restricting device reboots)

The "Support" section provides access to support tickets and updates, but not device operations like TSF & dump files.

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/reference-web-interface-administrator-access/web-interface-access-privileges/provide-granular-access-to-operations-settings#id81d24755-3919-4f77-9e85-db060e333121
The right answer is D Device -> Admin Roles -> Web UI -> Operations. I am with my PA-820 web UI open now. Threre is no Support option

D. Device > Admin Roles > Add > Web UI > Operations.
In version PAN-OS 10.2 all actions are under Web UI, operations. (Reboot, Tech support file and Stats Dump file).

D. Device > Admin Roles > Add > Web UI > Operations.

Options under Operations (PAN-OS 11.1):
- Reboot
- Generate Tech Support File
- Generate Stats Dump File
- Download Core Files
- Download Pcap Files

C. Device > Admin Roles > Add > Web UI > Support

The NetSec manager can configure the new firewall administrator role profile by navigating to Device > Admin Roles, clicking Add, and then selecting the appropriate options under the Web UI tab

Selected Answer: C
In the GUI it is Device > Support > Tech Support file / Stats Dump file

Selected Answer: C
Operations lets you reboot device etc
Support lets you generate tech support file and stats dump file etc

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/device/device-support

Selected Answer: C
Support -> TSF file
Operations -> Reboot device
Checked again, answer is D.

question said: must not be able to reboot the device.
Answer is C

Following are the option under, Device -> Admin Roles -> Add -> Web UI -> Operations:
1. Reboot
2. Generate Tech Support File
3. Generate Status Dump File
4. Download Core Files
5. Download PCAP Files

This is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
Virtual Router - Manage the routes on Layer3

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/configure-interfaces/layer-3-interfaces

A
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/configure-interfaces/layer-3-interfaces

A 
In a Layer 3 deployment, the firewall routes traffic between multiple ports. Before you can Configure Layer 3 Interfaces, you must configure the virtual router that you want the firewall to use to route the traffic for each Layer 3 interface.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/configure-interfaces/layer-3-interfaces

Selected Answer: A
Answer : A
A virtual router is a function of the firewall that participates in Layer 3 routing.

Selected Answer: A
A - Virtual router
